awd_titl_txt: Trade Agreements, Deep Integration and Welfare
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

Trade agreements increasingly focus on domestic policies such as product standards or environmental regulations, which has implications for society at large. The main objective of the project is to use rigorous economic analysis to examine the welfare impacts of deep-integration agreements. These are international trade agreements negotiated by considering the views of different interest groups. While the natural starting point of the project is an examination of shallow trade agreements that deal only with trade policies, this research focuses primarily on deep-integration aspects. The overarching insight is that a key determinant of the welfare effects of an international trade agreement depends on the structure of coalitions among different interest groups.

The reference point for this project is the canonical terms-of-trade model, in which there is no political-economy rationale for trade negotiations; in this model the only rationale for negotiations is to prevent countries from manipulating terms of trade. The approach in this project differs from the canonical one in several ways. The project considers a continuum of small countries, which have no ability to manipulate terms of trade, and take into account the role of interest groups in trade negotiations. In order to examine how agreements that incorporate the stance of interest groups affect welfare, the research distinguishes between the governments' positive objectives and a normative criterion. Finally, the project models regulatory policies in a novel way that is tractable and will highlight the different implications of product regulations that primarily deals with locally-sold products, and process regulations that are on the production processes used locally.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has generated a number of novel theoretical insights into the role of international regulatory cooperation. Below I summarize the main findings from the three key papers of the project. 

In "The Political Economy of International Regulatory Cooperation", co-authored with Ralph Ossa (University of Zurich), we examine the implications of international agreements on product standards and process standards on global welfare when such agreements are influenced by special interest groups. One important and novel insight is that the way in which international regulatory agreements impact global welfare when they are subect to lobbying pressures depends crucially on whether the interests of producers in different countries are aligned or in conflict. We show that the former situation tends to occur for product standards, while the latter tends to occur for process standards. We find that, if producer lobbies are strong enough, agreements on product standards lead to excessive de-regulation and decrease welfare, while agreements on process standards tighten regulations and enhance welfare.

The paper "Harmonization... What Else? The Role for International Regulatory Agreements," co-authored with Monika Mrazova (University of Geneva), extends the above-mentioned model with Ralph Ossa. In particular, we examine the potential role for international agreements on product standards when countries have different regulatory preferences and firms incur fixed costs of regulatory heterogeneity. We explore under what conditions countries choose to harmonize standards in a non-cooperative setting, and whether international cooperation should promote harmonization or encourage diversification of standards. One of our key findings is that, contrary to a view that is quite popular among policy makers and commentators, the role of international agreements should not necessarily be to encourage cross-border harmonization of standards, but it may well be to encourage diversification of standards.

In "International Climate Agreements and the Scream of Greta,' co-authored with Bob Staiger (Dartmouth College), we examine whether international environmental agreements can help avoid catastrophic climate outcomes. A key and novel aspect of this paper concerns the role of "intergenerational externalities", that is, the impacts of the current generation's policy choices on future generations. We find that, due to intergenerational externalities, environmental agreements can play only a limited role in preventing climate catastrophes, even abstracting from issues of free-riding in participation and compliance. If countries face a common threshold of catastrophe, environmental agreements have a role to play during the warming phase, by internalizing the international climate externalities and slowing the world's march to the brink, but they have no role to play in saving the world from collapse, because once the brink is reached countries have sufficient incentives to avoid catastrophe even without an agreement. Furthermore, the outcome implemented by the agreement falls short of the socially optimal outcome, which requires the world to move even more slowly toward the brink and possibly avoid the brink altogether. If the catastrophe threshold varies across countries, on the other hand, we find that the role of environmental agreements is potentially more expansive, because it may save some of the most vulnerable countries from collapse, but its limitations relative to the socially optimal outcome are potentially more devastating, because it may not save enough countries from collapse.
